title: R40913
content: The United States has historically had abundant natural resources, but increasing industrialization and population growth led to a growing dependence on foreign sources of energy in the 20th century. This dependence prompted federal efforts to increase energy independence and reduce domestic consumption. The United States relied on foreign sources of energy in the 20th century, prompting federal efforts to increase energy independence and reduce domestic consumption. This led to the establishment of programs focused on energy efficiency, conservation of resources, and research into renewable energy sources. Many of these programs have been in place for almost 40 years and have been redesigned multiple times. Since the 20th century, the United States has focused on reducing foreign energy dependence and domestic consumption through various energy efficiency and conservation programs. These programs have been continuously redesigned over almost 40 years to adapt to changing economic conditions and national interests, covering sectors from industry to academia and state/local governments to rural communities. Congress has periodically reauthorized and redesigned these programs since 2005 to address current needs and future challenges. Many energy programs have been periodically reauthorized and redesigned to meet changing economic conditions and national interests. They apply broadly to various sectors and have been designed to address current needs and future challenges. Congress has enacted several major energy laws since 2005. Since 2005, Congress has enacted major energy laws like EPACT 2005, EISA, EIEA, and ARRA, which established energy efficiency and renewable energy programs. DOE operates the most incentive programs in this area. The American Recovery and Reinvestment Act (ARRA; P.L. 111-5) and other energy laws have established various federal programs for energy efficiency and renewable energy research and development. The Department of Energy (DOE) operates the majority of these programs, with other departments such as Treasury, Agriculture, Interior, Labor, Housing and Urban Development, Veterans Affairs, and Small Business Administration also offering some programs. These programs provide grants, loans, and loan guarantees. The Department of the Treasury, Agriculture, Interior, Labor, Housing and Urban Development, Veterans Affairs, and Small Business Administration operate federal programs providing grants, loans, and incentives for energy efficiency, conservation, and renewable energy RDD&D.
